questions.text: A group of investigators is studying the effects of a novel drug, Drug X, on bile acid synthesis in patients with cholelithiasis. Drug X specifically targets the rate-limiting enzyme involved in bile acid synthesis. Which of the following enzymes does this drug most likely target?
questions.solution:
Bile is a greenish liquid made by the liver and stored in the gallbladder. Major solute components of bile include bile salts (bile acids conjugated to glycine or taurine, making them water-soluble) and phospholipids, with cholesterol and bile pigments (e.g. bilirubin) making up only a tiny percentage.  

Bile is first manufactured in the liver by cells called hepatocytes. Hepatocytes use an enzyme called 7-alpha-hydroxylase to convert cholesterol into two primary bile acids, cholic acid, and chenodeoxycholic acid. Some of these primary bile acids get dehydroxylated in the intestines, giving rise to secondary bile acids–specifically, deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid. The liver can conjugate or attach the amino acids glycine or taurine to all four of these bile acids, which ultimately gives rise to 8 different forms of bile salts. These bile salts are the main component of bile. Therefore, bile is made in the liver and flows into the intestines.

 Bile helps with digestion and absorption of lipids and fat-soluble vitamins (e.g., vitamins A, D, E, and K) as well as bilirubin and cholesterol excretion and has antimicrobial activity (via membrane disruption). It is important to note that bile production is the primary mechanism by which the body can excrete cholesterol and bilirubin.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetyl-CoA carboxylase:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid synthesis.
❌ Carnitine acyltransferase I:
Incorrect:  This answer choice is incorrect. Carnitine acyltransferase I is the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid oxidation.
❌ HMG-CoA synthase:
Incorrect:  This answer choice is incorrect. HMG-CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme in ketogenesis.  
❌ HMG-CoA reductase:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis.
✅ Cholesterol 7α-hydroxylase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An investigator studies the fate of conjugated bilirubin once it is released into the intestine. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding the excretion of conjugated bilirubin?

choices.text: Conjugated bilirubin is metabolized further during its passage along the biliary tree
Most of the bilirubin is unconjugated by the enteric bacteria in the small intestine
90% of the conjugated bilirubin circulates enterohepatically via the intestinal lumen
The majority of urobilinogen is lost in the urine
Bilirubin is extensively metabolized in the colon, producing urobilinogen and stercobilinogen

questions.solution:
The bile containing the conjugated bilirubin flows into the intestines. In the intestines, certain bacteria hydrolyze and reduce conjugated bilirubin into a colorless compound called urobilinogen, which can enter various pathways. When it's in the intestines, most of the urobilinogen, also called stercobilinogen, becomes oxidized by gut bacteria to form stercobilin. Stercobilin is what makes feces brown in color.   

There’s a system by which bilirubin and bile acids are recycled, called the enterohepatic circulation. A small amount of urobilinogen not excreted in the feces gets reabsorbed from the gut into the bloodstream. Some of that urobilinogen (~10%) travels through the blood to the kidneys, where it is converted to urobilin, which is very water-soluble and therefore excreted into the urine, giving urine its yellow color. The remainder goes back to the liver to be sent out into the intestines.  



Option Analysis

❌ Conjugated bilirubin is metabolized further during its passage along the biliary tree:
Incorrect: Conjugated bilirubin is neither further metabolized nor absorbed during its passage along the biliary tree.  
❌ Most of the bilirubin is unconjugated by the enteric bacteria in the small intestine :
Incorrect: In the small intestine, there appears to be little deconjugation or additional bilirubin metabolism in the healthy gut.  
❌ 90% of the conjugated bilirubin circulates enterohepatically via the intestinal lumen:
Incorrect: Bilirubin does not circulate enterohepatically to any significant degree, likely because it cannot be taken up from the intestinal lumen in its conjugated form, and once unconjugated in the colon it is rapidly metabolized to other products.  
❌ The majority of urobilinogen is lost in the urine:
Incorrect: Only about 10% of urobilinogen travels through the blood to the kidneys, where it is converted to urobilin, which is very water-soluble and therefore excreted into the urine, giving urine its yellow color.  
✅ Bilirubin is extensively metabolized in the colon, producing urobilinogen and stercobilinogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of abdominal pain and bloody stools. The symptoms began three-weeks ago. The abdominal pain is intermittent and usually self-resolves within an hour. Past medical history is noncontributory. She has been meeting all developmental milestones. Physical examination reveals a nontender and nondistended abdomen with normal bowel sounds. Laboratory testing reveals the following:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  15.2 g/dL 
 Platelet count  260,000/mm3 
 Prothrombin time  14 seconds 
 Partial thromboplastin time  32 seconds 
 
A radiolabeled technetium-99 scan is performed and reveals increased uptake in a structure located in the right lower abdominal quadrant. The walls of this structure will most likely consist of which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient has a Meckel diverticulum, which occurs due to incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct (also termed omphaloenteric duct). The remnant that is left behind is called a Meckel diverticulum. It is a “true” diverticulum since there is outpouching of all three layers of the intestinal wall (mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis). In contrast, most other diverticula, such as diverticulosis, are “false” and contain only the mucosa and submucosa layers.  

Meckel diverticulum typically follows the rule of twos: it affects 2% of the population, is twice more common in males, is 2 inches long, is found within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve in the small intestine, and contains 2 types of ectopic tissue: gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue. The gastric mucosa secretes acid, and the pancreatic tissue secretes alkaline juices, both of which can erode the intestinal walls.    

Most patients are asymptomatic but some can develop abdominal pain and bleeding. Moreover, it can be a lead point for volvulus, intussusception, and subsequent bowel obstruction.  

The condition is diagnosed using a technetium-99 scan (“Meckel scan”), which can detect ectopic gastric mucosa in the intestines; therefore, Meckel diverticulum lacking gastric mucosa will not be seen on a Meckel' scan.

Option Analysis

✅ Mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis layers :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mucosa and submucosa layers only :
Incorrect: Patients with diverticulosis will have outpouching of only the mucosa and submucosa layers. The muscularis layer is unaffected. Diverticulosis typically affects elderly individuals with a history of constipation. It would be atypical for diverticulosis to manifest in a young child. 
❌ Mucosa layer only :
Incorrect: This patient has a history of intermittent abdominal pain and bloody stools. These symptoms raise concern for a Meckel diverticulum, which is characterized by outpouching of all three layers of the intestinal wall.  
❌ Granulomas and lymphoid aggregates :
Incorrect: Granulomas and lymphoid aggregates are seen in Crohn disease. The condition can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal pain. However, it would be atypical for Crohn disease to manifest in a child this young. Moreover, results of the patient’s technetium-99 uptake scan are more consistent with the presentation of a Meckel diverticulum. 
❌ Fibrous bands of scar tissue :
Incorrect: This answer describes adhesions, which can occur after abdominal surgery. Adhesions can potentially cause a bowel obstruction. However, this pathology would not account for the increased technetium-99 uptake in the right lower abdominal quadrant, which suggests that there is ectopic gastric mucosa.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for jaundice and poor muscle tone. She was born full-term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient was jaundiced at birth and her symptoms have persisted. She is exclusively breastfed and produces 5-6 wet diapers per day. Family history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus in her father and asthma in her mother. Physical examination shows jaundice and reduced muscle tone throughout the body. In addition, the patient has a right eye downward gaze palsy. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Total bilirubin  23.0 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  14 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  12 U/L 
Which of the following conditions will present with laboratory findings similar to those found in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s physical exam is notable for jaundice, which is abnormal yellowish pigmentation of the skin, as well as hypotonia and oculomotor palsy. These findings, in combination with laboratory testing notable for unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, are concerning Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I. Of note, a patient’s unconjugated bilirubin level can be calculated by subtracting the conjugated bilirubin level from the total bilirubin level.  

Hyperbilirubinemia can be divided into three categories: unconjugated, conjugated, and mixed. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (also termed indirect hyperbilirubinemia) is caused by increased breakdown of hemoglobin (e.g., hemolytic disease of the newborn), impaired hepatic bilirubin uptake (e.g., congestive heart failure, side-effect of medications such as rifampin and probenecid), or defective conjugation of bilirubin (e.g., Crigler-Najjar syndrome, Gilbert Syndrome).  

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is caused by decreased bilirubin excretion (e.g., Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome) or biliary tract obstruction (e.g., biliary atresia, primary sclerosing cholangitis).  

Mixed hyperbilirubinemia is caused by conditions that impair both bilirubin conjugation and excretion. It is commonly seen in individuals with hepatitis and cirrhosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Biliary atresia:
Incorrect: Patients with biliary atresia will have conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, since bilirubin can be conjugated but not eliminated into the intestines. In contrast, this patient has normal conjugated bilirubin levels and elevated unconjugated bilirubin.
❌  Viral hepatitis:
Incorrect: This condition will lead to mixed hyperbilirubinemia, which means that both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin levels are elevated. Additionally, liver enzymes are typically elevated due to hepatocellular damage. In contrast, this patient’s laboratory findings show normal conjugated bilirubin levels and liver enzymes.
✅ Crigler-Najjar syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dubin-Johnson syndrome:
Incorrect: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a condition characterized by an absence of a biliary transport protein found normally found in hepatocytes. This results in less conjugated bilirubin being transported from hepatocytes into the bile canaliculi, ultimately causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In contrast, this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
❌ Primary sclerosing cholangitis:
Incorrect: Primary sclerosing cholangitis causes fibrosis of the biliary tree. Over time, this can impair bile outflow and result in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In contrast, the patient in this case has elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider because of “yellowing of the skin.” Two days earlier, the patient was started on trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for bacterial cystitis. The patient previously had a similar episode during college after a viral upper respiratory tract infection. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he currently uses an albuterol inhaler. Family history is notable for hypertension in his mother and peripheral vascular disease in his father. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice of the skin. Peripheral blood smear reveals Heinz bodies and bite cells. Which of the following laboratory findings will be most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  Normal  ↑
Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  Normal  Normal
Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  ↑  Normal

questions.solution:
This patient likely has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, a condition characterized by red blood cells that are vulnerable to hemolysis when exposed to oxidative stress. Potential triggers include fava beans, medications (e.g. TMP-SMX), and infections. The hemoglobin released from lysed cells is either converted to unconjugated bilirubin or excreted via urine. As a result, G6PD deficiency causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and increased urine hemoglobin levels.  

Other causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia include conditions that increase hemoglobin breakdown (e.g. hemolytic disease of the newborn), impaired hepatic bilirubin uptake (e.g. congestive heart failure), or impaired bilirubin conjugation (e.g. Crigler-Najjar syndrome).  

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia can cause jaundice and scleral icterus. Since unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble, it can also deposit in the brain when concentrations are high enough. This phenomenon causes kernicterus, also termed bilirubin encephalopathy, which is a potentially fatal condition characterized by jaundice and neurological problems. In addition, patients will have increased concentrations of unconjugated bilirubin in the bile, which can result in the formation of small, black, pigmented gallstones.  

Option Analysis

✅   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  Normal  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  Normal  Normal:
Incorrect: This patient likely has increased hemolysis secondary to glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. Hemolysis causes increased quantities of hemoglobin to be released. The hemoglobin is either converted into unconjugated bilirubin or excreted in the urine. The latter will cause patients to have elevated urine hemoglobin levels. 
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  Normal ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be caused by impaired bilirubin excretion or biliary tract obstruction. Potential causes range from Crigler-Najjar syndrome (unlikely in this adult patient) to primary sclerosing cholangitis. However, none of those potential etiologies would cause Heinz bodies or bite cells.
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  ↑  Normal:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with mixed hyperbilirubinemia, which is most often caused by hepatitis or cirrhosis. However, this patient lacks risk factors for either of these conditions. Moreover, this patient has no physical examination findings, such as ascites or hepatosplenomegaly, that would be concerning for hepatitis or cirrhosis.
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  Normal Normal  Normal:
Incorrect: These findings would be seen in a healthy individual. However, this patient has jaundice and scleral icterus, which are indicative of elevated bilirubin levels.

questions.text: A 3-hour-old male neonate is observed to have profuse drooling and coughing in the nursery after the first attempt at feeding. The patient was born at 39-weeks gestational age to a 27-year-old, gravida 2 para 2, mother via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Cardiac exam reveals a harsh holosystolic murmur most prominent at the left lower sternal border. The nurse attempts to pass a nasogastric tube into the patient’s stomach but encounters resistance after advancing 12 cm. Which of the following physical exam findings will most likely also be present in this patient?

choices.text: Protrusion of intestines through a paraumbilical defect
Presence of blood in the feces
Reduced breath sounds in the left chest

questions.solution:
This patient likely has esophageal atresia, which is when the esophagus does not develop properly and ends in a blind pouch. Since these babies have difficulty swallowing, they can present with excess drooling and vomiting after eating. In addition, this patient has coughing, which raises concerns for a fistula between the esophagus and trachea. The presence of a tracheoesophageal fistula allows food to enter the respiratory tract, causing choking, cyanosis, and aspiration pneumonia. Lastly, the patient’s heart murmur is concerning for a ventral septal defect (VSD).    

Taking into account the aforementioned symptoms, the patient likely has the VACTERL association. This acronym stands for: Vertebral abnormalities, Anal atresia, Cardiac defects, Tracheoesophageal fistula, Esophageal atresia, Renal abnormalities, and Limb defects. Among the answer choices, only hypoplasia of the upper extremities (Option D) is part of the VACTERL association.  

A diagnosis of esophageal atresia can be made by attempting to pass a catheter (e.g. nasogastric tube) into the stomach. The tube often cannot be passed farther than 10-15 cm. The diagnosis can then be confirmed by a chest x-ray, which will show the catheter coiled in the esophageal pouch.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Protrusion of intestines through a paraumbilical defect :
Incorrect: This answer describes gastroschisis, which is when a child’s intestines extend outside of the abdomen through a hole next to the umbilicus. However, gastroschisis is usually an isolated pathology, and it is not associated with esophageal atresia.  
❌ Presence of blood in the feces :
Incorrect: A Meckel diverticulum can cause abdominal pain and bloody stools. However, this patient most likely has esophageal atresia. Studies have not demonstrated an association between esophageal atresia and Meckel diverticulum. 
❌ Frequent sweating and sneezing :
Incorrect: Patients with neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome can have increased drooling, sweating, and sneezing. However, this patient’s increased drooling is more likely due to esophageal atresia. This diagnosis is supported by the history of polyhydramnios (due to impaired swallowing of amniotic fluid) and resistance encountered while inserting a nasogastric tube.  
✅ Hypoplasia of the upper extremities :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Reduced breath sounds in the left chest :
Incorrect: Pulmonary hypoplasia or a diaphragmatic hernia can cause this finding. However, this patient’s history of polyhydramnios, increased drooling, and difficulty passing a nasogastric tube is most consistent with the presentation of esophageal atresia. Studies have not demonstrated an association between esophageal atresia and the aforementioned conditions.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old female is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of jaundice which began 3 weeks ago. In addition, according to the mother, the patient’s urine has become progressively darker and is “yellowish-brown” in color. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Her blood is type A, Rh-negative. The mother’s blood is type AB, Rh-positive. The patient is exclusively breastfed and products between 6-7 wet diapers daily. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, as well as jaundice of the head and neck. Abdominal exam is notable for a firm and enlarged liver. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Total bilirubin  7.2 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  6.5 mg/dL 
 Alkaline phosphatase  115 U/L 
Which of the following best describes the most likely cause of this patient’s finding?

choices.text: Red blood cell destruction by maternal antibodies
Impaired elimination of bilirubin via feces
Fibro-obliterative destruction of extrahepatic bile ducts

questions.solution:
This patient likely has biliary atresia, a childhood condition characterized by fibro-obliterative destruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree. The exact cause of biliary atresia is unknown; however, it is hypothesized to be caused by biliary tract inflammation secondary to viral infections or toxins. The biliary tree is totally obstructed by the end of the third week after birth.  

Patients with biliary atresia have normal birth weight and weight gain. However, they will eventually develop jaundice, hepatomegaly, acholic stools, and dark urine (since the water-soluble conjugated bilirubin is now exclusively eliminated via urine). Physical examination will reveal a firm and enlarged liver. Laboratory testing will reveal increased levels of conjugated bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transferase.

Diagnosis of the condition can be made using cholangiogram (radiographic imaging of the biliary tree) and liver biopsy. The biopsy will show intrahepatic bile duct proliferation, fibrosis and edema, and obstructed bile ducts. Surgical intervention, which may involve linking the liver directly to the small intestines, is needed to enable bile outflow and prevent progression to biliary cirrhosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Red blood cell destruction by maternal antibodies:
Incorrect: Hemolytic disease of the newborn can be caused by Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility. It would cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and manifest with symptoms shortly after birth. In contrast, it would be atypical for hemolytic disease of the newborn to present with symptoms 4 weeks after birth.
❌ Impaired elimination of bilirubin via feces:
 Incorrect:  Breastfeeding failure jaundice typically occurs within the first week of life. It is due to poor breast milk intake. As a result, these babies have inadequate stooling and decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces. However, breastfeeding failure jaundice would not cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia on laboratory findings or hepatomegaly on physical exam.   
✅ Fibro-obliterative destruction of extrahepatic bile ducts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced glucuronidation of bilirubin:
Incorrect: This answer describes Crigler-Najjar syndrome, a congenital condition caused by reduced or absent UDP-glucuronosyl transferase activity. It can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice. In contrast, this patient has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  
❌ Lymphocytic infiltration of bile ducts:
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is an autoimmune condition that damages the biliary tract. The condition most often affects middle-aged females with autoimmune conditions. Overtime, PBC can lead to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase. However, it would be atypical for PBC to affect a newborn.

questions.text:
A 2-hour-old male neonate develops difficulty breathing while in the nursery. He was born at 36-weeks gestational age via a vaginal delivery. Prenatal development was complicated by maternal gestational diabetes. The patient’s vitals are notable for tachypnea. Physical exam reveals nasal flaring and intercostal retractions. The apical impulse is displaced to the right. Imaging is ordered, and the results are as follows:
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s respiratory presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which is when a malformation of the diaphragm leaves a hole that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity. It is due to impaired development of the pleuroperitoneal membranes, the embryological structures that give rise to the diaphragm. Since the pleuroperitoneal membranes on the left-side take longer to develop, hernias are more frequently located on this side (as indicated by the red arrow in the radiograph).      

The herniated abdominal organs can push against the developing lung (causing pulmonary hypoplasia), the blood vessels supplying the lungs (causing pulmonary hypertension), and the heart (causing a displaced apical impulse). After birth, patients can present with tachypnea, respiratory distress, and cyanosis.  

Diagnosis is made using chest radiography, which shows herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.  

Option Analysis

❌  Aspiration of meconium  :
Incorrect: This answer describes meconium aspiration syndrome, which occurs when meconium enters the airways and causes obstruction. It is most often seen in post-term infants. In contrast, this patient is preterm. Moreover, meconium aspiration syndrome would not account for the displaced apical impulse or imaging findings, which demonstrate bowel loops in the thoracic cavity. 
✅ Severe pulmonary hypoplasia :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inadequate pulmonary surfactant production:
Incorrect: Inadequate surfactant production can result in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Maternal diabetes and preterm birth are risk factors. However, X-ray imaging will show ground glass opacities and air bronchograms. Thus the presence of bowel loops in the thorax is inconsistent with the presentation of this condition. 
❌ Free radical induced lung damage:
Incorrect: Oxygen therapy can result in the production of free radicals that can injure organs, resulting in pulmonary dysplasia and blindness. However, this neonate has no history of supplemental oxygen therapy. 
❌  Infection by gram-positive organism :
Incorrect: An infection by bacteria, such as Streptococcus agalactiae, can cause sepsis and tachypnea. However, an infection would not account for the displaced apical impulse or radiographic findings.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for epigastric pain that began an hour ago. He reports that the pain radiates to the back and is 9 out of 10 in severity. The patient consumes a diet rich in fresh fruits and vegetables. He drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week on social occasions. Family history is notable for recurrent episodes of pancreatitis in his father and paternal uncle. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 125/83 mmHg, and pulse is 96/min. Physical examination is notable for tenderness on light palpation of the epigastric region. Abdominal exam also reveals hepatosplenomegaly and the following finding:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Xanthomas are found on the patient’s bilateral elbows. Which of the following set of laboratory findings would be most likely expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has type IV familial hyperlipidemia (also termed familial hypertriglyceridemia), an autosomal dominant condition caused by hepatic overproduction of VLDLs. In addition, lipoprotein lipase activity is decreased, which prevents the breakdown of VLDLs and chylomicrons. Since VLDLs and chylomicrons both contain mainly triglyceride, serum triglyceride levels are markedly elevated.  

This condition is characterized by premature atherosclerosis and an increased risk of developing acute pancreatitis, such as in this patient, who is presenting with the classic pain distribution (e.g., epigastric pain radiating to the back) and the skin findings consistent with Cullen’s sign (periumbilical ecchymosis). The high concentration of serum triglycerides can activate pancreatic cells, causing them to release lipase which breaks the triglycerides down into free fatty acids; excess free fatty acids can subsequently injure the pancreas.  

Option Analysis

❌  Serum Triglyceride Serum Cholesterol Serum Lipase ↑  Unchanged  ↑ :
Incorrect: Patients with type I familial hyperlipidemia present with elevated triglyceride levels and normal cholesterol levels. These patients are at increased risk of pancreatitis, which causes elevated serum lipase levels. However, type I familial hyperlipidemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. In contrast, this patient’s father has similar symptoms, suggesting that an autosomal dominant condition is the underlying cause.
❌   Serum Triglyceride  Serum Cholesterol  Serum Lipase Unchanged  ↑ Unchanged:
Incorrect: This patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back and skin findings consistent with Cullen’s sign (periumbilical ecchymosis). All of these findings are suggestive of pancreatitis, which presents with an elevated serum lipase.
❌  Serum Triglyceride Serum Cholesterol Serum Lipase ↑   ↑ Unchanged:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette has epigastric pain radiating to the back and periumbilical bruising, termed Cullen’s sign. These findings are highly suggestive of pancreatitis, and an elevated lipase is expected.
✅   Serum Triglyceride  Serum Cholesterol  Serum Lipase  ↑   ↑  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Serum Triglyceride Serum Cholesterol Serum Lipase Unchanged  Unchanged  ↑ :
Incorrect: Individuals with normal cholesterol and triglyceride levels can also develop pancreatitis, which presents with an elevated serum lipase level. Potential causes include obstructive gallstones, abdominal trauma, or alcohol abuse. However this patient’s xanthomas and family history of pancreatitis raise concerns for familial dyslipidemia, which causes elevated triglycerides and/or cholesterol.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant boy is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of non-bilious vomiting that is precipitated by feeding. He was born at 38-weeks gestational age to a 23-year-old, gravida 1 para 1, woman via a vaginal delivery. During pregnancy, the patient’s mother was diagnosed with Chlamydial cervicitis and prescribed azithromycin, which successfully treated the infection. Physical exam is notable for sunken anterior and posterior fontanelles. Abdominal exam is notable for a firm mass palpated in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory testing is ordered. Which of the following findings will most likely be present?
questions.solution:
This patient has pyloric stenosis, which is when an infant’s pyloric sphincter hypertrophies and causes gastric outlet obstruction. First-born males and maternal use of macrolide antibiotics while pregnant are risk factors.

Patients with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis have a normal gut function at birth. However, symptoms develop around two to six weeks of life. Patients can develop projectile vomiting after feeding. Of note, the vomitus is non-bilious, since bile is secreted into the duodenum, which is distal to the pyloric sphincter.    

Laboratory testing will reveal hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. This pattern is because the loss of stomach acid (hydrochloric acid) leads to hypochloremia and dehydration. Dehydration activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This activation causes the kidneys to retain sodium and excrete potassium, resulting in hypokalemia. Hypokalemia causes the movement of potassium out of cells and hydrogen ions into cells, as well as secretion of hydrogen ions and reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the kidneys. The net result is metabolic alkalosis.    

Patients will have an “olive-shaped” mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant. Ultrasound is used to confirm the condition. Treatment involves pyloromyotomy, which is when the pylorus muscle is surgically cut.

Option Analysis

✅   Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.50  3.3  90  :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.50  5.3  90  :
Incorrect: Vomiting of gastric contents can cause volume depletion and activate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system. This system increases sodium reuptake and potassium excretion in the kidney’s collecting tubules. The net result is hypokalemia.
❌  Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.40  4.0  100 :
Incorrect: These are normal lab findings, which may be seen in patients with mild vomiting. However, this patient most likely has severe vomiting given he has signs of dehydration (e.g., sunken fontanelles). As a result, a hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis would most likely be present.
❌  Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.30  3.3  90  :
Incorrect: Conditions such as diarrhea may cause bicarbonate loss and result in a metabolic acidosis. However, the patient in this vignette has repeated vomiting, which will most likely cause a metabolic alkalosis due to gastric acid loss and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system.
❌  Serum pH  Serum Potassium   Serum Chloride  7.30  5.3  90  :
Incorrect: Vomiting contributes to volume depletion and subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system. Aldosterone increases sodium uptake and potassium excretion in the kidney’s collecting tubules, resulting in hypokalemia. Aldosterone also increases hydrogen ion excretion by the kidneys, resulting in a metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text:
A 5-month-old female is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of jaundice that began after a viral upper respiratory tract infection. She was born at 39 weeks gestation to a 27-year-old, gravida 1 para 1, woman via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The patient has been meeting developmental milestones. Family history is noncontributory. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and diffuse jaundice. Abdominal and neurological exams are unremarkable. Blood testing is performed and reveals the following:  
Laboratory value  Result 
Hemoglobin  13.9 mg.dL 
 Leukocyte count  6,800/mm3 
 Total bilirubin  12.7 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Alanine  aminotransferase  15 U/L 
 Aspartate  aminotransferase  16 U/L 
Phenobarbital is administered, and repeat total serum bilirubin is measured at 7 mg/dL. Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces

questions.solution:
This patient has Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, a condition characterized by reduced UDP-glucuronyl transferase (UDPGT) activity. It is less severe than Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I. Patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II develop unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but the total bilirubin is usually below 20 mg/dL. In contrast, individuals with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I often have total bilirubin exceeding 20 mg/dL.  

Patients with this condition can develop jaundice and, in rare cases, neurological deficits secondary to kernicterus. Patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II have good response to treatment with phenobarbital, which increases UDPGT synthesis and subsequently increases conjugation of unconjugated bilirubin. In contrast, patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I do not respond to phenobarbital therapy, because there is a complete absence of UDPGT enzyme activity.    

Option Analysis

❌ Absent UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity:
Incorrect: This answer describes Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I. However, patients with this condition would not respond to phenobarbital, and thus no decline in total serum bilirubin would occur after administration.  
✅ Reduced UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Defective multidrug resistance protein 2:
Incorrect: This answer describes Dubin-Johnson syndrome. Multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2) is involved in the transport of conjugated bilirubin out of hepatocytes and into the bile canaliculi. Patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome have conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, whereas this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 
❌ Imapired replenishment of glutathione:
Incorrect: This answer describes glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. The condition can predispose patients to hemolysis after exposure to oxidative stress, causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, phenobarbital would not reduce unconjugated bilirubin levels in patients with G6PD deficiency.  
❌ Decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces:
Incorrect: Breastfeeding failure jaundice typically occurs during the first week of life and is due to poor breast milk intake. As a result, these babies have inadequate stooling and decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces. However, it would be atypical for breastfeeding failure jaundice to present in a 5 month old child with no signs of malnutrition or dehydration.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain that started two hours ago. He reports that the pain radiates to the back and is 8 out of 10 in severity. The patient eats a well-balanced diet, consumes 1-2 beers per week, and denies recent abdominal trauma. Family history is notable for hypertension in his father. Physical examination shows pain on light palpation of the epigastric region. Hepatosplenomegaly is noted. Multiple small red-yellow papules are present on the patient’s buttocks and shoulders. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  
 
Laboratory value Result 
Sodium  139 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
 Calcium  7.9 mg/dL 
 Triglyceride  860 mg/dL 
 Serum Cholesterol (Total)  190 mg/dL 
 Lipase  310 U/L 

A deficiency in which of the following proteins is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has type I hyperlipidemia (also termed hyperchylomicronemia), an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by elevation of chylomicrons in the blood. It occurs most often due to lipoprotein lipase deficiency. A rarer cause is a defect in apolipoprotein C-II, a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase. Without a functional lipoprotein lipase, the breakdown of chylomicrons and their triglyceride content is prevented, resulting in massive triglyceride accumulation within the blood.  

The massive triglyceride content in the blood results in cutaneous deposition and rapid development of xanthomas on the back and buttocks that can be pruritic. Due to the rapid nature of their development, they are called eruptive xanthomas. In addition, the high concentration of serum triglycerides can lead to acute pancreatitis. This is because when pancreatic cells encounter triglycerides, they release lipase to break the triglycerides down into free fatty acids; excess free fatty acids can injure the pancreas. Lastly, patients can develop hepatosplenomegaly.  

Of note, patients with type I hyperlipidemia are not at increased risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. This is because the development of atherosclerotic plaques is related to the elevation of other lipoproteins such as low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and not related to the elevation of chylomicrons.  

Laboratory testing will show markedly elevated triglyceride levels and normal/mildly elevated cholesterol levels. Another important sign is that when fasting serum is chilled, the chylomicrons will form a white, creamy layer at the top of the test tube, as seen in the image below.  


Image reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons   

Option Analysis

❌ Apolipoprotein C-II:
Incorrect: A defect in apolipoprotein C-II can result in familial hyperlipidemia type I. The condition presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pancreatitis, and eruptive xanthomas. However, a deficiency in apolipoprotein C-II accounts for less than 20% of cases. The vast majority of cases (80%) are caused by defects in lipoprotein lipase.  
❌ Apolipoprotein E:
Incorrect: Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) is involved in lipoprotein remnant uptake. A defect with ApoE presents with premature atherosclerosis, increased risk of acute coronary syndrome, and palmar xanthomas. However, it would be atypical for an ApoE defect to present with pancreatitis or eruptive xanthomas.
✅ Lipoprotein lipase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pancreatic lipase:
Incorrect: A defect in this enzyme can cause poor fat absorption and a deficiency in fat-soluble vitamins. As a result, patients with pancreatic lipase deficiency have low serum triglyceride levels. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has markedly elevated serum triglyceride levels, favoring another diagnosis.
❌ Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase helps break down fatty acids into acetyl-CoA. A defect in this protein can cause hypoketotic hypoglycemia, which presents with seizures, vomiting, and coma. The condition is usually diagnosed shortly after birth and would not present with eruptive xanthomas and pancreatitis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider seeking evaluation of jaundice. Two days ago, the patient participated in a marathon race. He had a similar episode in college after an episode of binge drinking. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies and hepatitis A infection, which he acquired one-year ago while travelling overseas. In the office, his temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 118/65 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and diffuse jaundice. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Urinalysis reveals no significant findings. The patient’s blood work reveals the following findings:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.2 mg.dL 
 Leukocyte count  6,800/mm3 
 Total bilirubin  4.1 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  14 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  17 U/L 
Which of the following best explains the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Liver injury secondary to viral proliferation
Impaired excretion of bilirubin from the liver

questions.solution:
This patient has Gilbert syndrome, a benign autosomal recessive condition characterized by mildly reduced UDP-glucuronosyl transferase (UDPGT) activity. This enzyme is involved in conjugating bilirubin, and therefore, patients with Gilbert syndrome have hepatocytes that are less effective at conjugating bilirubin. This relative deficiency can result in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Gilbert syndrome is fairly common, and between 4-16% of individuals (depending on the population studied) have the condition.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic. However, they can develop mild jaundice when exposed to triggers that increase hemolysis/bilirubin production. Potential triggers include fasting, febrile illness, fatigue, stress, and physical exertion, all of which induce mild hemolysis.  

Laboratory testing will reveal mildly elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels and normal liver function tests.

Option Analysis

✅ Mildly reduced UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Absent UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity:
Incorrect: This answer describes Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1. Patients exclusively present in the neonatal period with markedly elevated bilirubin levels, which often exceed 20 mg/dL. In addition, patients will have persistent jaundice and kernicterus. In contrast, this patient has mildly elevated bilirubin levels, no neurological deficits, and intermittent episodes of jaundice triggered by stressors.
❌ Liver injury secondary to viral proliferation:
Incorrect: Patients with viral hepatitis can develop injury and jaundice. However, this patient’s hepatitis A infection occurred a year ago, and the infection self-resolves. Moreover, this patient has normal liver enzyme levels, making liver injury unlikely.
❌ Impaired excretion of bilirubin from the liver:
Incorrect: This answer describes Dubin-Johnson syndrome and Rotor syndrome. However, both of these conditions will cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In contrast, this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
❌ Reduced glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase activity:
Incorrect: Patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency have red blood cells that are vulnerable to hemolysis when exposed to oxidative stress. This hemolysis can lead to increased hemoglobin release and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, patients may also have anemia or increased urine hemoglobin. In contrast, this patient has a normal hemoglobin and urinalysis results.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider’s office for evaluation of recent skin changes. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies. She is not currently taking any medications. Her father passed away from a myocardial infarction at 32-years-old, and her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her paternal grandfather passed away from colorectal cancer at 62-years-old. Her vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows several subcutaneous nodules found above the Achilles tendon bilaterally. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Sodium  141 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.0 mEq/L 
 Serum Glucose (Fasting)  87 mg/dL 
 Triglyceride  144 mg/dL 
 Serum Cholesterol (Total)  325 mg/dL 
Which of the following conditions is this patient most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
This patient has type II familial hyperlipidemia, an autosomal dominant condition caused by defects in low density lipoprotein receptors or apolipoprotein B-100. The condition presents with premature atherosclerosis, early-onset coronary artery disease, and tendon xanthomas. Laboratory findings will reveal markedly elevated cholesterol levels but normal/mildly elevated triglyceride levels.  

The symptoms of hyperlipidemia can vary depending on the type and severity. Skin manifestations include xanthomas, which are deposits of fat under the skin and in the tendons. These occur when extremely high blood levels of lipoproteins or triglycerides leak out of the blood vessels. When these deposits occur around the eyelid, they are called xanthelasma. In addition, lipids can deposit around the cornea, creating a brown ring of fat called a corneal arcus. Lipid deposition in the liver can cause fatty liver disease, also called hepatic steatosis.   

The most worrisome complication of the familial hyperlipidemias is early-onset atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, including coronary artery disease, stroke, peripheral vascular disease and carotid artery stenosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy can be secondary to poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. The patient’s mother has diabetes mellitus, and there is a genetic component to the disease. However, the patient's most recent blood sugar level is within normal range, making diabetes unlikely in this patient.
✅ Premature atherosclerosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinitis pigmentosa:
Incorrect: Patients with abetalipoproteinemia may present with retinitis pigmentosa. The condition manifests in infancy. It causes fat malabsorption and failure to thrive. Patients present with the consequences of deficiency in fat-soluble vitamins, such as easy bruising (vitamin K), osteopenia (vitamin D), and worsening vision (vitamin A). In contrast, the patient in this vignette has none of these symptoms.
❌ Iron deficiency anemia:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal tract malignancies may cause occult blood loss and iron deficiency anemia. This patient has a family history of colorectal cancer. However, she does not have any other symptoms of the condition such as unexplained weight loss, and her skin and laboratory findings are better explained by another diagnosis.  
❌ Acute pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Patients with type I or type IV familial hyperlipidemia are at increased risk of pancreatitis, in the setting of significantly elevated triglycerides. In contrast, this patient’s family history of early-onset acute coronary syndrome, presence of Achilles xanthomas, and elevated cholesterol raise concerns for type II familial hyperlipidemia. Type II familial hyperlipidemia does not typically cause pancreatitis.

questions.text:
A 6-week-old infant boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of an abdominal bulge. His mother noticed the protrusion a few days ago while bathing him. The patient is exclusively breastfed and produces 6-7 wet diapers per day. According to his mother, the patient has had no vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. He is at the 65th percentile for both height and weight. Examination of the patient’s abdomen reveals the following:
 

Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best accounts for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Impaired lateral wall migration during embryologic development
Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct
Incomplete closure of the processus vaginalis
Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membranes

questions.solution:
This patient has a congenital umbilical hernia, which occurs when the intestines herniate through a weakened umbilical fibromuscular ring. However, unlike an omphalocele or gastroschisis, the intestines are fully covered by skin, and the hernia looks like a protruding bulge from the belly button. The bulge can enlarge when intra-abdominal pressure is increased, such as when coughing or crying.  

Most umbilical hernias are asymptomatic and 90% self-resolve within the first 2-5 years of life. However, a large hernia can cause bowel strangulation, resulting in ischemia and necrosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired lateral wall migration during embryologic development :
Incorrect: An omphalocele occurs when the lateral folds fail to migrate and fuse at the umbilical ring. It manifests as herniated abdominal contents surrounded by a layer of peritoneum. In contrast, no abdominal contents with peritoneum are seen herniating from this patient. 
❌ Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct :
Incorrect: This answer describes a Meckel diverticulum. While largely asymptomatic, this condition can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal pain. However, it would be atypical for a Meckel diverticulum to manifest as a protruding mass at the anterior abdomen. 
❌ Incomplete closure of the processus vaginalis :
Incorrect: This pathophysiology leads to the formation of an indirect inguinal hernia, which can present as a bulge in the groin. However, this patient’s bulge is at the umbilicus. 
❌ Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membranes :
Incorrect: This answer describes a diaphragmatic hernia. It can cause intra-abdominal contents to enter the thoracic cavity and impair lung development. As a result, patients can develop respiratory distress. In addition, patients can present with a scaphoid abdomen (flattened abdomen) since a sizable amount of the intra-abdominal contents have shifted into the chest. In contrast, none of these findings are observed in this patient. 
✅ Weakened umbilical fibromuscular ring :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to his outpatient provider seeking evaluation for intermittent groin pain. The pain is worse when he is lifting weights in the gym and improves with rest. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. Physical exam reveals a left-sided bulge in the groin that increases in size with coughing and Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Acquired weakness of the transversalis fascia
Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis

questions.solution:
This patient has an indirect inguinal hernia. It occurs when the processus vaginalis, an embryonic outpouching of the peritoneum, fails to obliterate, and a portion of the intestines is able to herniate into the inguinal canal. Indirect inguinal hernias manifest as a bulge that is lateral to the lower epigastric vessels. It passes through both the internal and external inguinal rings.  

A similar condition is direct inguinal hernia. It is often seen in elderly men and caused by weakened abdominal muscles and fascia. The condition manifests as a bulge medial to the lower epigastric vessels and passes through only the external inguinal ring.  

Both conditions can cause groin pain, especially when there is increased abdominal pressure. In males, the intestine can protrude into the scrotum, causing pain and a sensation of fullness in the testicles. If bowel strangulation occurs, there will be acute-onset abdominal pain accompanied by nausea, vomiting and possibly fever.  


Option Analysis

❌ Acquired weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: This answer describes a direct inguinal hernia, which is most often seen in elderly men. In contrast, it would be atypical for a direct inguinal hernia to manifest in an otherwise healthy teenager. 
❌  Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membranes :
Incorrect: Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membranes results in a diaphragmatic hernia. This defect can allow abdominal contents to herniate into the thoracic cavity. However, this patient’s hernia is located in the groin.  
✅ Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Weakness of the linea alba :
Incorrect: This pathology causes an epigastric hernia, which can manifest anywhere between the xiphoid process and umbilicus. However, an epigastric hernia would not manifest as a bulge in the groin. 
❌  Widening of the femoral ring :
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of a femoral hernia, which can present as a palpable mass found below the inguinal ligament. The condition is most commonly diagnosed in middle-aged females. In contrast, it would be atypical for a femoral hernia to present in a young male.
